name: Logging Infrastructure.txt - Fundamentals
description: This section explains the two primary methods used to collect log data in the logging infrastructure: log forwarding using FluentD/Filebeat agents, and log fetching from S3. It also introduces Sumologic as the existing solution for log management, which accepts logs via HTTP endpoints and installed agents, indexes the data into partitions, and provides a dashboard for viewing and querying the data.
use_cases: Collecting logs from managed infrastructure using FluentD/Filebeat agents
Collecting logs from unmanaged infrastructure by fetching from S3
Viewing and querying log data using Sumologic dashboard
Indexing log data into partitions in Sumologic
capabilities: HTTP endpoints (HTTP Collectors) for log ingestion
Installed agents (Installed Collector) for log ingestion
Querying log data using Sumologic's query language and functions

name: Logging Infrastructure.txt - Sumologic – Existing Solution
description: This section explains the existing logging infrastructure used by the organization, which is Sumologic. It describes how logs are collected from various sources like Docker containers and PHP applications, and pushed to Sumologic using FluentD. Sumologic provides features like data retention, compliance with regulations, access control, and dashboarding. The section also mentions an alternative logging solution based on AWS Elasticsearch Service, which is being explored for cost savings and as a fallback option.
use_cases: Compliance with regulations (e.g., RBI data localization requirements)
Access control and role-based access management
capabilities: Proprietary WORM (Write Only Read Many) Store for data immutability
Log collection from Docker containers and log files
Log forwarding to AWS S3 for archiving
Scheduled searches and dashboarding on indexed data
Cost-effective log storage with AWS Elasticsearch Service and UltraWarm storage
Log indexing and rotation using FileBeat
